revision.text:
{{Infobox comics creator | image = | imagesize = | caption = | birth_name = Molly Maud Kiely | birth_date = October 10, 1969 | birth_place = [[Bracebridge, Ontario]], [[Canada]] | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = American | cartoonist = y | notable works = [[Eros Comix]] titles | website =http://mollykiely.com | subcat = American }} '''Molly Maud Kiely''' (born October 10, 1969)<ref name=Lambiek>[http://www.lambiek.net/artists/k/kiely_molly.htm Kiely entry], ''Lambiek's Comiclopedia''. Accessed Mar. 6, 2014.</ref><ref name="about"/> is an [[United States|American]] alternative [[cartoonist]] best known for [[erotica]].<ref>[[Tom Spurgeon|Spurgeon, Tom]] (October 25, 2015), "[http://www.comicsreporter.com/index.php/fff_results_post_434_dirty_comics/ FFF Results Post #434 -- Dirty Comics]", [[Comics Reporter]]. Retrieved April 13, 2017</ref> Her work is published by [[Fantagraphics]]/[[Eros Comix]] and has influenced other artists such as [[Jess Fink]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Chevat|first=Zoe|title=The Mary Sue Interview: Sexy Comics Artist Jess Fink!|url=https://www.themarysue.com/the-mary-sue-interview-sexy-comics-artist-jess-fink/|website=The Mary Sue|accessdate=April 14, 2017}}</ref>
Kiely was born in [[Bracebridge, Ontario]], raised in [[Kitchener, Ontario|Kitchener]], and attended the [[University of Waterloo]].<ref name="JO">Vasseur, Richard (June 11, 2007), "[http://www.jazmaonline.com/interviews/interviews2007.asp?intID=492 Molly Kiely Artist of Gothic Classics]", Jazma Online. Retrieved April 15, 2017</ref> She has liked drawing her whole life,<ref name="JO"/> and discovered comics through ''[[Krazy Kat]]'' and ''[[Li'l Abner]]''.<ref>Keller, Katherine, "[http://www.sequentialtart.com/archive/feb00/13quest_0200.shtml She's That Kind of Girl]", Sequential Tart. Retrieved April 15, 2017</ref> She created her first minicomic in 1991 at the [[San Diego Comic-Con]].<ref name="tomc">Dowers, Michael, "[https://books.google.com/books?id=QbkhDAAAQBAJ&pg=PA4&dq=Treasury+of+Mini+Comics+volume+2+Molly+Kiely&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj1w6bI7qfTAhXFTCYKHY34AXkQ6AEIIjAA#v=onepage&q=Treasury%20of%20Mini%20Comics%20volume%202%20Molly%20Kiely&f=false Treasury of Mini Comics Volume Two]" pp300-301. Retrieved April 15, 2017</ref> She left [[Canada]] for [[San Francisco, California|San Francisco]] in 1992.<ref name=Lambiek />
Her first comic, ''Communion'', was a collaboration with J. Hagey based on a stream-of-consciousness poem about a one-night stand.<ref name="tomc"/> It was published by the [[Eros Comix]] imprint of [[Fantagraphics]] in 1992.<ref name="sqt">Mayerson, Ginger (February 4, 2006), "[http://www.sequentialtart.com/archive/feb04/art_0204_4.shtml Erotica, Utopia and Judicial Proceedings]", Sequential Tart. Retrieved April 15, 2017</ref> In 1993, [[Wooley Comics]] commissioned her to do a comic adaptation of [[Marquis de Sade]]'s novel ''Philosophy in the Bedroom''.<ref name="sqt"/>
She describes her work as "clean line style" that has been compared to [[Aubrey Beardsley]] and [[Jaime Hernandez]].<ref name="JO"/>
The pornographic nature of her work sometimes draws judgement from feminists who see her as helping men exploit women.<ref>Hall, Ed (April 28, 2011), "[http://burnaway.org/review/chester-5000-xyv-pornography-and-feminism-in-the-graphic-novel/ Chester 5000 XYV: Pornography and feminism in the graphic novel]", Burnaway. Retrieved April 15, 2017</ref> Under Subsection 163 of the Canadian Criminal Code, the [[Canada Border Services Agency|Canadian Customs]] and [[Canada Post|Post Office]] occasionally confiscated Kiely's work when it was being mailed between her and Eros in 1995.<ref name="sqt"/>
She had a daughter with her husband in 2007<ref name="tomc"/> before being widowed in 2015.<ref name="about">"[http://mollykiely.com/about/ About]", Official website. Retrieved April 14, 2017</ref> Kiely now resides in [[Tucson, Arizona]] with her daughter.<ref name=Lambiek /><ref name="about"/>
==Selected bibliography== * ''Communion'', 1992 (written by [[Jonathan Hagey]]) * ''Philosophy in the Bedroom'', 1993 * ''Diary of a Dominatrix'', 3 volumes, 1994–1995 * ''Sass'', 1995<ref>Kirby, Robert (February 26, 2015), "[http://www.tcj.com/reviews/treasury-of-mini-comics-volume-two/ Treasury of Mini Comics Volume Two]", [[The Comic Journal]]. Retrieved April 15, 2017</ref> * ''Saucy Little Tart'', 5 volumes, 1995–1997 * ''That Kind of Girl'', 1999 * ''Tecopa Jane'', 2000 * ''On Your Knees Boy'', 2002 * Adaptation of [[Murasaki Shikibu]]'s ''[[The Tale of Genji]]'' in the anthology ''The Graphic Cannon'', edited by [[Russ Kick]]<ref>Armitage, Hugh (September 17, 2013), "[http://www.digitalspy.com/comics/news/a515843/5-graphic-novels-to-improve-your-mind-neurocomic-xkcd-more/ 5 graphic novels to improve your mind: 'Neurocomic', 'xkcd', more]", [[Digital Spy]]. Retrieved April 13, 2017</ref>
